mail_login.description: Returns a `MetaMail` entity if the login has been correct. In case an issue appeared this function will return `null`.

parent_path.description: Returns a `string` which is the potential parent path of the path provided. Keep in mind that the path provided needs to be properly formatted.

hasIndex.description: Depending on data type this function checks if the provided index is available inside the value. To get a better idea about the behaviour look into the `hasIndex` methods related to `string`, `list` and `map`.

typeof.description: Returns a `string` containing the type of the entity provided. There are following types by default: "string", "number", "function", "map", "list", "null", "file", "shell", "computer", "metaMail", "metaLib", "metaxploit", "crypto", "port", "router", "netSession", "service", "subWallet", "wallet", "coin", "aptClient", "blockchain". Custom types can be added as well by using the `classID` propery in a map.

get_router.description: Returns by default the `router` to which the executing computer is connected to. Optinally an IP address can be provided. In case of failure `null` is returned.
example: print("Router is equal to network gateway.")
print("Router is not equal to network gateway.")

get_switch.description: Returns the switch on the local network whose IP address matches, otherwise it returns `null`.

nslookup.description: Returns the IP address for the provided web address. In case the web address cannot be found a `string` gets returned containing the following message: "Not found"

print.description: Print a message on the Terminal. Optionally replacing can be enabled which will replace the previous print. This can be useful for creating a loading bar for example. There is also the possibility of styling output by using TextMeshPro rich-text tags.

clear_screen.description: Removes any text existing in a Terminal previous to this point.

active_user.description: Returns a `string` with the name of the user who is executing the current script.

home_dir.description: Returns a `string` with the home folder path of the user who is executing the current script.
example: print("Home dir of current user: " + home_dir)

get_shell.description: Returns the `shell` that is executing the script. Optionally a username and password can be provided. In case the username or password do not match an existing user this method will return `null`.

indexes.description: Depending on data type this function returns a list with all available indexes. To get a better idea about the behaviour look into the `indexes` methods related to `string`, `list` and `map`.

values.description: Depending on data type this function returns a list with all available values. To get a better idea about the behaviour look into the `values` methods related to `string`, `list` and `map`.

indexOf.description: Depending on data type this function searches for the index of the provided value. To get a better idea about the behaviour look into the `indexOf` methods related to `string`, `list` and `map`.

len.description: Depending on data type this function returns the length of the provided value. To get a better idea about the behaviour look into the `len` methods related to `string`, `list` and `map`.

shuffle.description: Depending on data type this function will shuffle data. Instead of returning the newly shuffled data this function will mutate the data. To get a better idea about the behaviour look into the `shuffle` methods related to `list` and `map`.

val.description: Casts a `string` to a `number`. In case the provided `string` does not represent a valid `number` the `number` zero will get returned.

lower.description: Returns a `string` which is the lowercase transformed version of the provided `string`.

upper.description: Returns a `string` which is the uppercase transformed version of the provided `string`.

sum.description: Depending on data type this function return the sum of all items. To get a better idea about the behaviour look into the `sum` methods related to `list` and `map`.
example: print("Sum of all items is: " + sum(list))

pop.description: Depending on data type this function will return the last item in the provided value. Additional this function removes the last item and therefore mutates the object. To get a better idea about the behaviour look into the `pop` methods related to `list` and `map`.

pull.description: Depending on data type this function will return the first item in the provided value. Additional this function removes the first item and therefore mutates the object. To get a better idea about the behaviour look into the `pull` methods related to `list` and `map`.

push.description: Depending on data type this function will append a value to the provided object. As a result the object will get mutated. To get a better idea about the behaviour look into the `push` methods related to `list` and `map`.
example: print("The answer to everything is: " + pop(list))

sort.description: Depending on data type this function will sort the values in the provided object. As a result the object will get mutated. To get a better idea about the behaviour look into the `sort` methods related to `list` and `map`.

remove.description: Depending on data type this function will remove a value in the provided object. As a result the object will get mutated. To get a better idea about the behaviour look into the `remove` methods related to `list` and `map`.

user_input.description: Puts script execution on hold in order to receive input from the user. Input will be submitted by pressing Enter. Additionally it is also possible to style the output message by using TextMeshPro rich-text tags. There are two optional arguments. If the passwordMode flag is `true` the input will be masked by asterik signs. In case the anyKey flag is `true` instead of waiting for the Enter key to be pressed any key press will be captured instantly.
example: key = user_input("Press arrow up/down to change value.", false, true)

include_lib.description: Enables to include library binaries which can be used inside your script. In case of success an object will get returned related to the provided library. Otherwise `null` gets returned. Keep in mind that this function can be only used for library binaries. In case you want to import custom scripts or binaries into your project you should use `import_code` instead.

import_code.description: Enables to import code from different sources into one file. This is useful in case you want to split code into different files and also to avoid any limitation in regards of text file character limits. Note that `import_code` requires an absolute path and is called while compiling the file into a binary instead of during runtime. Additionally `import_code` cannot be nested. Code can be either imported from plain text files or binaries that have "allow import" enabled.

exit.description: Stops any execution of the currently running script. Optionally a message can be provided which will be shown in the Terminal. There is also the possibility of styling output by using TextMeshPro rich-text tags.

user_mail_address.description: Returns a `string` containing the email address of the user who is executing the script.

user_bank_number.description: Returns a `string` containing the bank number of the user who is executing the script.

whois.description: Returns a `string` containing the administrator information behind an IP address provided. In case of failure the returned `string` will contain an error message instead.

wait.description: Puts script execution on hold. Optionally the duration can be provided via the time argument. By default the duration will be 1 second. The duration cannot be below 0.01 or above 300.

command_info.description: Returns a `string` containing the help text for common commands. Including commands provided by the Operation System. Commands such as mkdir, whois, ls, sudo etc.

program_path.description: Returns a `string` containing the path of the script that is currently executed.

current_path.description: Returns a `string` containing the path in which script that is currently executed from.

format_columns.description: Returns a `string` which is the formatted version of the provided text. Keep in mind that TextMeshPro rich-text tags might srew up the output. When using tags consider applying these after formatting.

current_date.description: Returns a `string` containing the current date and time. The format is as follows: "[day]/[month]/[year] - [hours]:[minutes]". Here an example: "27/Jan/2000 - 08:19"

is_lan_ip.description: Returns `true` in case the provided IP address is a valid Lan IP address. Otherwise `false` will get returned.

is_valid_ip.description: Returns `true` in case the provided IP address is valid. Otherwise `false` will get returned.

bitwise.description: Enables to perform bitwise operations. Supported operators are: "&", "|", "^", "<<", ">>", ">>>". Returns a `number`.

example: print("Difference between a and b is: " + difference)

acos.description: Returns the inverse cosine (in radians) of a `number`.

asin.description: Returns the inverse sine (in radians) of a `number`.

atan.description: Returns the inverse tangent (in radians) of a `number`.

tan.description: Returns the tangent of a `number` in radians.

cos.description: Returns the cosine of a `number` in radians.

code.description: Returns the unicode `number` of the first character of the string. In case an empty `string` is provided the script execution will crash.
example: key = user_input("Press a key!", false, true)

char.description: Returns the unicode character `string` related to the provided unicode `number`. The provided `number` needs to be between 0 and 65535. Any `number` which is outside this range will cause the script to throw a runtime error.
example: key = user_input("Press a key!", false, true)

sin.description: Returns the sine of a `number` in radians.

floor.description: Returns `number` rounded down to the integer value of the provided `number`.

range.description: Returns a `list` where each item is a `number`. By default the `list` starts with the `number` zero and incrementing by one each item. Optionally start and end can be defined. Additionally the incremental value can be changed as well. In case the incremental value is zero this function will throw a runtime error.

round.description: Returns `number` rounded to the integer value of the provided `number`.

rnd.description: Returns a random `number` between 0 and 1. Optionally a seed `number` can be provided this seeds a random `number` generator with the given value.
example: input = user_input("Guess a number between 10 and 20!").to_int
print("You failed! The number was " + output)

sign.description: Returns a one or minus one, indicating the sign of the number passed as argument. If the input is zero, it will be returned as-is.

sqrt.description: Returns the square root of a `number`.

str.description: Returns the `string` value of provided data. Can be used to turn a `number` into a `string` or to get the signature of a `function`.

ceil.description: Returns `number` rounded up to the integer value of the provided `number`.

pi.description: Returns the `number` PI to the precision of six.

launch_path.description: Returns a `string` containing the path of the script that is currently executed.

slice.description: Returns a sliced `list`. Valid data types for slicing are `string` and `list`. The returned `list` will contain all elements related to the provided start and end index.

md5.description: Returns the md5 hash `string` of the provided `string`.
example: print("Hash for the password 'test' is " + passwordHash)

hash.description: Returns numeric hash for the provided data.

time.description: Returns a `number` of seconds representing the elapsed time since the script got started.

bitAnd.description: Permorms a bitwise AND for the provided values. Returns a `number`.

bitOr.description: Permorms a bitwise OR for the provided values. Returns a `number`.

bitXor.description: Permorms a bitwise XOR for the provided values. Returns a `number`.

log.description: Returns the natural logarithm of a `number`. By default the base is 10. Optionally the base can be changed.

get_custom_object.description: Returns `map` which shared throughout all script executions. Can be helpful in case forwarding an entity is desired.

insert.description: Depending on data type this function will insert a value to the provided index. Due to the insertion the object will be mutated. To get a better idea about the behaviour look into the `insert` method related to `list`.
